in the Pyanj River Basin

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will undertake climate risk assessments, 
project preparation, capacity building support, and policy advice to a series of ensuing projects in 
the agriculture, natural resources, and rural development (ANR) sector in Tajikistan. The ANR 
sector plays an important role in ensuring sustainable and inclusive economic growth in the 
country. It has a high priority in the National Development Strategy of the Republic of Tajikistan 
2030.1 The transaction TA facility will contribute to a strategically aligned and climate adaptive 
investment  pipeline.  The  ensuing  proposed  projects  comprise  the  Rural  Productivity 
Enhancement Sector Project and the Climate Change Adaptation Project. To enhance project 
readiness of the ensuing proposed projects, the transaction TA facility will be complemented by 
project readiness financing (PRF).2  
 
a.  Background 
 
2.    Agriculture’s relevance to the economy. Since 2010, Tajikistan’s agriculture sector 
experienced volatile but strong average growth rates of about 6% each year. It accounts for more 
than half of the country’s total employment and contributed around 22% to the gross domestic 
product in 2019.3 About 70% (over 6.5 million) of the Tajik population (9.5 million) lives in rural 
areas where small-scale household farming is the major source of household incomes. Cotton 
and wheat are the primary crops that are planted on nearly three quarters of the entire cultivated 
area of Tajikistan (which is 700,000 hectares). 
 
3.         Persistent rural poverty. The proportion of the population living below the national poverty 
line decreased from 34% in 2013 to 26% in 2019. There is a wide urban-rural divide in poverty 
levels. While urban poverty declined from 22% to 18%, rural poverty remained at very high levels 
of 30% between 2018 and 2019.4 The average national progress in poverty reduction is impacted 
by the coronavirus disease pandemic. Poverty reduction rates are expected to decelerate, 
disproportionately affecting low-income and rural communities.  
 
4.         Remaining food security and nutrition challenges. The country is highly vulnerable to 
food insecurity and malnutrition. The prevalence of moderate to severe food insecurity was about 
30% in 2019.5 Because of the coronavirus disease pandemic, the food security situation has since 
worsened. Over 40% of the population is experiencing very high rates of food insecurity.6 
 
b.  Sector Challenges 
 
5.       Vulnerability to climate change and natural hazards. Climate change impacts and 
natural hazards are the main challenges for the country’s vulnerable agriculture sector. Climate 
change models suggest a significant rise in the annual probability of droughts, increasing from 
3% to over 25% till mid-century.7 Droughts, in combination with heat stress and the increased 
 
1  Republic of Tajikistan. 2016. National Development Strategy of the Republic of Tajikistan for the period up to 2030. 
Dushanbe. 
2  Climate Adaptive Investments in the Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Rural Development Sector (2022). 
3  ADB. 2021. Key Indicators Tajikistan. 
4  World Bank. 2020. Poverty in Tajikistan 2020 Infographic.  
5  FAO. 2019. The State of Food Security and Nutrition in the World. 
6  ADB. 2021. Asian Development Outlook 2021 Update: Transforming Agriculture in Asia. Manila. 
7  World Bank. Climate Change Knowledge Portal (CCKP 2020). Tajikistan. Climate Data. Projections.

2 
 
water demand for key crops, will further reduce agricultural yields. These could result in a 
deterioration of the already fragile food and nutrition security situation. The frequency of heat days 
above 40° Celsius is expected to rise with associated increases in gastrointestinal infection rates 
in both humans and livestock. Increases in water and foodborne diseases are also likely. 
 
6.        Variations in snowfall and air temperature will impact rivers supplying water for agriculture 
and add to the water competition with other sectors. Changes in river flow regimes will lead to 
less water being available during the period of highest crop water demand, thus, impacting 
irrigation. This will result in decreased crop and livestock productivity, if left unmanaged.8  
 
7.         Tajikistan is also highly vulnerable to natural hazards, including earthquakes, flash floods, 
and landslides. The challenges are amplified by a lack of awareness, knowledge, and capacity 
among communities and government institutions to adopt risk mitigation measures. This places 
sustainable development of rural agricultural areas at risk.9 Poor pasture management and 
overgrazing leads to soil degradation and the general deterioration of watershed areas. The latter 
contributes to an increased risk of landslides and mud flows. 
 
8.       Inefficient water resources management. More than 90% of agriculture production comes 
from irrigated lands but irrigation efficiency in the country remains critically low at 30%. Low 
productivity exacerbates food insecurity and places additional stress on finite water resources.10 
About 40% of the irrigated area has pumped water supply with associated high energy costs.11  
 
    c.  Opportunities 
 
9.          The TA facility will provide an opportunity for strategic investment planning in the Pyanj 
river basin and will build on the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) ongoing activities.12 ADB has 
been active in the Pyanj river basin since 2007 and has provided support to (i) strengthen the 
climate  resilience  of  irrigation  and  water  supply  infrastructure;  (ii)  enable  the  Agency  for 
Hydrometeorology to produce timely and accurate forecasting of weather events; and (iii) develop 
the  Pyanj  River  Basin  Management  Plan  (PRBMP).13  This  supports  the  future  planning, 
development, and sustainable management of water resources within the basin. The TA facility 
will augment the PRBMP by adding climate risk considerations and by identifying opportunities 
for downscaling climate impacts on local levels within the river basin. 
 
10.   The TA facility will enable an integrated approach to natural resources management in the 
Pyanj river basin, with consideration for potential climate adaptive interventions. Upstream climate 
analysis will enhance the understanding of climate impacts on rural livelihoods, especially on 
women and marginalized groups. It will also identify areas within the basin with the highest 
exposure to climate change and prioritize actions to build more resilient communities. The ensuing 
projects under the TA facility aim to be climate adaptation projects and will address climate risks 
as one of their primary objectives (Type II projects).14 
 
8  World Bank. 2020. Climate change in Central Asia. Illustrated. 
9  ADB and World Bank. 2021. Climate Risk Country Profile: Tajikistan. 
10 Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe. 2017. Agricultural Water Management in Tajikistan. 
11 World Bank. 2020. Exposure and Practical In-Roads to Modernizing Irrigation in Central Asia. Final Report. 
12 ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan, Grant, and 
Administration of Grant and Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Water Resources 
Management in Pyanj River Basin Project. Manila. 
13 The Pyanj River Basin Management Plan was developed under the ADB. 2016 Water Resources Management in  
Pyanj River Basin Project (TA 9183) 
14 Rural Productivity Enhancement Sector Project for concept paper approval 2022 and the Climate Change Adaptation 
Project for concept paper approval 2023 (tentative).

3 
 
11.  The TA facility and the ensuing projects will foster gender equality. Tajikistan ranks 123rd 
out  of  148  countries  on  the  global  gender  gap  index,  scoring  low  on  women’s  economic 
participation and political empowerment.15 Women do not have equal access to knowledge, land, 
and inputs for improved agricultural productivity. The TA facility and its ensuing projects will 
improve the role, financial empowerment, and capacity of women in the ANR sector.  
 
12.   The TA facility will also promote digitalization and the use of advanced technologies.16 
This will strengthen data and information availability for decision making, and for climate risk and 
vulnerability assessments. A needs assessment and feasibility study will be developed focusing 
on a digital system to improve watershed management. It will focus on livestock, specifically 
animal registration, including tagging with microchips. Such a system will allow the Ministry of 
Agriculture to have a better understanding of the type and number of livestock in the basin, 
ownership  (including  sex-disaggregated  data)  and  for  undertaking  genetic  surveillance  of 
livestock.  
 
13.  The TA facility will support ADB’s Strategy 2030 and its operational priorities by (i) 
addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental  sustainability;  (iv)  promoting  rural  development  and  food  security;  and  (v) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity.17  
 
14.  The TA facility is aligned with government priorities, specifically in terms of a coordinated 
effort to holistically address climate change in agriculture and water resources management. The 
Government of Tajikistan highlights the importance of the reduction of climate change vulnerability 
through an integrated sector approach in its Nationally Determined Contributions. It promotes 
sustainable forms of agriculture considering climate change in its National Action Plan for Climate 
Change Mitigation while its National Water Sector Reform Program 2016–2025 emphasizes the 
importance of social, economic, and environmental interests. 18  
 
15.  Lessons learned. A comprehensive approach is required in supporting project processing 
and implementation to effectively address climate change impacts on the ANR sector. This 
includes identifying suitable interventions which can better respond to the sectors’ challenges 
within the context of climate change. Using a TA facility, instead of single project TAs, can support 
a  more  consistent  and  holistic  approach  across  the  project  portfolio  and  can  be  more 
administratively efficient. ADB’s ANR portfolio has suffered from low project readiness, delays in 
contract awards and disbursements, and time overruns. It is also characterized by mainly stand- 
alone investments, rather than strategic and efficient lending modalities. The TA facility will 
consider suitable options for a more efficient delivery of ANR sector investments. 
 
B.   Outputs and Activities 
 
16.  Output 1: Climate change impacts on rural communities and livelihoods identified. 
The output builds on the PRBMP to enhance the understanding of the impact of climate change 
 
15 World Economic Forum. 2018. The Global Gender Gap Report. Geneva. 
16 Individual consultants and resources persons will be funded under the ongoing ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance for 
Digital Solutions to Improve Agricultural Value Chains. Manila (TA 9902) which has earmarked $200,000 to support 
digitalization for climate-adaptive agriculture in Tajikistan. 
17 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
18 Government of Tajikistan. Water Sector Reform Program 2016–2025, and National Action Plan for Climate Change 
Mitigation. Dushanbe.

4 
 
to the catchment areas. The activities will include upstream climate change assessments and 
vulnerability mapping for better targeted project activities that go beyond climate proofing of 
infrastructure and increase focus on building climate-resilient livelihoods. Specific studies and 
consultations will focus on the impact of climate change on women, marginalized groups, and 
local agricultural production systems. 
 
17.  Output 2: Climate-resilient agriculture, natural resources, and rural development 
investment projects prepared. The TA facility will assist the government in preparing investment 
projects for ADB financing that have climate adaptation as one of their main priorities. The output 
focuses on due diligence assessments such as (i) technical suitability; (ii) economic and financial 
viability; (iii) governance; (iv) poverty impact and social and gender development; (v) financial and 
procurement risk assessment; and (v) social and environmental safeguards. During the TA 
facility’s implementation, lessons learned from previous projects will be incorporated into the 
preparation of new projects.19 
 
18.  Output 3: Capacity building and advisory support provided. The TA facility will 
provide the government with (i) project preparation and implementation support; (ii) capacity 
development in procurement, financial management and disbursement, safeguards, gender 
mainstreaming and project related technical aspects; (iii) policy advisory and sector assessments, 
and (iv) capacity development for adaptation planning on different government levels.  
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
19.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1,300,000, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($700,000 TASF 7 and $300,000 
TASF-other sources), and (ii) $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Climate Change 
Fund.  The  key  expenditure  items  are  listed  in  Appendix  1.  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  Outputs 1 and 3 activities may commence upon approval of the TA facility. Output 2 
activities will start after ADB approves the project concept paper of the first ensuing project 
covered by the TA facility. The TA facility will be implemented over three years, commencing in 
November 2021. 
 
21.  ADB will administer the TA, working closely with the designated counterparts.20 The 
Environment, Natural Resources, and Agriculture Division of ADB’s Central and West Asia 
Department will be responsible for the day-to-day implementation and will select, administer, and 
supervise the consultants’ outputs. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the 
table. 
 
 
 
 
19 PRF will enhance project readiness and supplement Output 2 activities by focusing on the development of detailed 
engineering designs and project location-based climate assessments, among other things. 
20 Agencies include the Ministry of Agriculture, the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources, the Committee for 
Environmental Protection and the Agency for Land Reclamation and Irrigation.

5 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  November 2021 – December 2024 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agencies  ADB with the implementing agencies of the ensuing projects 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
  Firm: QCBS  Preparation of Rural Productivity  $400,000 
(90:10)  Enhancement Sector Project 
(92 person-months)

(90:10)  and the preparation of Climate 
Change Adaptation Project 
(95.5 person-months) 
  Individual:  Capacity development, project  $200,000 
individual selection  support, and policy advice 
(17 person-months) 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020 as amended from time

Change Fund will be frontloaded.

arrangement upon TA completion  to the Government of Tajikistan. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection, TA = Technical Assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
22.  Consulting Services. ADB will engage the consultants following ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.21 The indicative 
consultants’ input allocation for the ensuing projects under the TA facility are shown in Appendix 
2. Two consultant teams will be engaged through firms. One team will work on the preparation of 
the Rural Productivity Enhancement Sector Project. The other team will work on conducting 
climate change assessments and the preparation of the Climate Change Adaptation Project. The 
recruitment of these consulting firms will follow a quality- and cost-based selection method (90:10 
ratio) using full, or simplified proposals. Individual consultants will be selected using the individual 
consultant’s selection method to provide specialized technical and administrative inputs to fulfill 
ADB due diligence requirements and enhance project readiness (10 person-months international, 
7 person-month national). A total of 187.5 person-months (97.5 international and 90.0 national) 
are expected to be contracted to the firms.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Republic of Tajikistan for Enhancing Climate Resilience in the Pyanj River Basin, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
 
21 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

contribution is estimated to account for less than 5% of the total TA cost.
